comments:
build M20040916-1125

If Table.getItems() is called from within a dispose listener, this causes an NPE.

The following shows the problem.

public class NPEInTableOnDispose {

	public static void main(String[] args) {
		Display display = new Display();
		Shell shell = new Shell(display);
		shell.setLayout(new FillLayout());
		final Table table = new Table(shell, SWT.NONE);
		table.addDisposeListener(new DisposeListener() {
			public void widgetDisposed(DisposeEvent e) {
				table.getItems();
			}
		});
		shell.pack();
		shell.setVisible(true);
		while (!shell.isDisposed()) {
			if (!display.readAndDispatch())
				display.sleep();
		}
	}
}

The stack is:

This looks somewhat similar to bug 45708, in that the Table looks half-disposed
there too, but that case was failing on the columns field being null, and I
didn't see a dispose listener involved.

This was first seen in an RCP example Jeff was working on using a TableViewer.

method, it hits this case, as in the stack below:

I'd expect getItems() to either succeed (returning either the previous items, or
empty array), or for it to fail with a WID.
Still happens in the 3.1 stream too.

Is there any kind of contract on the expected behaviour when a widget is called
during a dispose callback?

Here is a similar case, originating from a tjread in eclipse.platform.rcp
newsgroup: "Problem closing an RCP application"

- write an Eclipse view that uses a Tree
- hook a dispose listener on it that fails with an exception
- shutdown eclipse
- Tree.releaseWidget() gets called twice
  - the first time is when we're trying to close all workbench pages, and all
views within that page
  - the second time is when the window's shell gets disposed
- an NPE occurs the second time because it was only partially disposed, and not
unhooked from its parent

Should SWT be doing more to protect itself against failing listeners?
It's unclear what the workbench could do in this case.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 4416 ***
